item.title: Britain’s Prince Philip Hospitalized
item.description: Buckingham Palace said abdominal surgery had been planned following earlier tests and the prince, 91, was “in very good health.”
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: IHT Quick Read: June 7
item.description: The U.S. government discloses it has been collecting information on foreigners overseas; Putin announces he will divorce; aerospace defense contractors chase commercial customers; and niche art fairs thrive in London.
item.dc:creator: By THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE
item.media:description: Senators Dianne Feinstein and Saxby Chambliss spoke to reporters Thursday about the National Security Agency’s collection of millions of Verizon phone records.

item.title: Taliban Attack Base Guarded by Georgians in Afghanistan
item.description: The Georgian forces operate in perhaps the most dangerous part of the country, helping fill a void left by American troops who have been pulling out.
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN and TAIMOOR SHAH

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Detention of Critic of Child Abuse Draws Ire in China
item.description: Ye Haiyan, a campaigner for women and children and for sex workers’ rights, recently protested sex attacks on children, and then was herself reportedly attacked at home. Her subsequent sentence to 13 days detention has drawn widespread attention in China.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: A screenshot from Weibo of Chinese women holding signs that say: 'Principal, get a room with me; leave the kids alone!' Some signs say 'students'. Top left is Ye Haiyan, the detained critic of child sex abuse and campaigner for sex worker's rights.

item.title: Israel Prepares for an Uncertain Future
item.description: With Hezbollah joining in Syria’s two-year-old civil war, Israeli Defense Forces staged military exercises to prepare for a potential conflict with northern neighbors.

item.title: The Caucus: Leaks Overshadow Obama’s Meeting With President of China
item.description: The meeting with President Xi Jinping was expected to be a venue for Mr. Obama to raise concerns about Chinese cyber attacks and spying. Now, it will take place amid striking revelations about the United States’s surveillance of its own citizens.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL D. SHEAR

item.title: World Briefing | The Americas: Mexico: Army Rescues 165 Migrants Held by Kidnappers Near U.S. Border
item.description: According to Eduardo Sánchez, a spokesman for the Interior Ministry, the migrants were headed to the United States when they were swindled by smugglers along the border.
item.dc:creator: By KARLA ZABLUDOVSKY

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: West Bank: Palestinian Authority Swears In Its New Prime Minister
item.description: Rami Hamdallah was sworn in as prime minister of the Palestinian Authority, replacing Salam Fayyad, the internationally respected economist who resigned in April.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Europe Still Wrangling Over Online Privacy Rules
item.description: European justice ministers agreed Thursday to a business-friendly proposal, an early signal that lobbying efforts from the technology industry are gaining some traction.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES KANTER and SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.media:description: Google’s Street View device on the Matterhorn in Switzerland. The mapping project has been fined over improper data collection.

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iraq: Bombings Kill at Least 14 People
item.description: A series of car bombings in and around Baghdad killed 14 people and wounded dozens of others on Thursday, police officials said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Student Dies After a Beating
item.description: A 19-year-old student and left-wing activist, Clément Méric, died Thursday after being beaten by a group of people described as skinheads in the heart of a Paris shopping district.
item.dc:creator: By MAÏA de la BAUME

item.title: News Analysis: In Americas, Resistance to Legal Marijuana
item.description: Despite hints in Latin America about legalizing marijuana, a summit meeting revealed much opposition to loosening drug laws, and little consensus.
item.dc:creator: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD
item.media:description: María Ángela Holguín, Colombian foreign minister, at a meeting of an Americas bloc.

item.title: Israel’s Ultra-Orthodox Fight to Fit In
item.description: Israel has been consumed in recent months with the challenge of integrating the insular, swelling ultra-Orthodox minority, known as Haredim, into society.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:credit: Rina Castelnuovo for The New York Times
item.media:description: An ultra-Orthodox man waited to be interviewed at Mafteach, a Jerusalem employment agency whose name means “key.”

item.title: Obama Urged to Prod China on Human Rights
item.description: Relatives of political prisoners and 30 organizations called on President Obama to use his summit meeting with President Xi Jinping to highlight the issue of human rights abuses in China.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN LEE MYERS and ERIC SCHMITT

item.title: U.S. Says It Gathers Online Data Abroad
item.description: The federal government has secretly taken information on foreigners overseas for years from companies like Google, Facebook and Apple, the director of national intelligence confirmed.
item.category: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
item.dc:creator: By CHARLIE SAVAGE, EDWARD WYATT and PETER BAKER
item.media:description: Senators Dianne Feinstein and Saxby Chambliss spoke to reporters Thursday about the National Security Agency’s collection of millions of Verizon phone records.

item.title: Putins Finally Appear Together, to Announce Split
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia announced that he plans to divorce his wife of 29 years, Lyudmila, who for years has barely appeared in public.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY and DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and his wife, Lyudmila, last year.

item.title: Turkish Leader Says Razing of Park to Proceed
item.description: At a news conference in Tunis, Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan refused to yield to the demands of protesters in dozens of Turkish cities.
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO and SEBNEM ARSU
item.media:description: Protestors at Gezi Park in Taksim Square on Thursday.

item.title: Meissen Journal: In Flooded Areas of Europe, Familiar Feelings and New Questions
item.description: In the eyes of many along the Elbe and the Danube, it is not too early to raise questions about why the region was hit again so soon after record flooding in 2002.
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA EDDY
item.media:description: Vaclav Reichl dried family photographs that he saved from his home in the town of Putim in the Czech Republic.

item.title: Cui Tiankai, China’s Envoy to U.S., Aims to Allay Tensions
item.description: Cui Tiankai, the country’s ambassador in Washington, is its chief behind-the-scenes facilitator for President Xi Jinping and President Obama’s meeting.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ
item.media:description: Cui Tiankai, the Chinese ambassador to the United States, at a news conference last year.

item.title: Syrian Forces Pursue Insurgents Who Fled Fallen Town
item.description: After routing rebels from the town of Qusayr, the Syrian Army and Hezbollah pursued hundreds of insurgents and civilians fleeing to surrounding villages and farms.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
International Committee of the Red Cross
item.dc:creator: By HWAIDA SAAD and KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: Ghana Arrests Chinese in Gold Mining Regions
item.description: Authorities have rounded up 169 Chinese citizens since June 1, detaining them for deportation, in the latest sign of tensions between the two countries.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER and BREE FENG

item.title: Bangladesh Factory Collapse Survivor Leaves Hospital
item.description: Reshma Begum, who survived for 17 days in the rubble of a collapsed garment factory, fielded many job offers before accepting work at the Westin Hotel in Dhaka.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.media:credit: Munir Uz Zaman/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Reshma Begum, who survived in the rubble of Rana Plaza for 17 days, took a job at the Westin Hotel in Dhaka, Bangladesh.

item.title: India Ink: For International Students, College Checklists for June
item.description: College counselors in the United States offer monthly advice for juniors and seniors who want to stay on track during the admissions process.
item.dc:creator: By KRISTEN LEARNER, JEFFREY WONG and NIKKI MAGAZINER MILLS

item.title: The Lede: With Cameras Rolling, Egyptian Politicians Threaten Ethiopia Over Dam
item.description: Egypt’s president, Mohamed Morsi, told a room full of politicians who had just laid out all the covert ways that their country could stop a Nile River dam project in Ethiopia that they were on live television.
item.dc:creator: By LIAM STACK

item.title: Americans Skeptical on Role in Foreign Conflicts, Poll Finds
item.description: Nearly six in 10 people say the United States should not take a leading role in trying to solve conflicts, The New York Times/CBS News poll found.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER and ALLISON KOPICKI
